div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly..as under for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Oriental Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Saturday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUTH (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, calling fortnightly at LARNACA (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardahelles, Gallipoli anf Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sedan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

Mail Steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sina), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden. For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Fort Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK and SON (Eygypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIEA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Landing to ALEXANDRIA, CARIO, SYRIA, etc. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc. from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns.
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
EXCLUSION OF KOREA.
FRANCE'S PROPOSAL UNSUPPORTED.

div.p: The Korean delegates have sent letters to the other delegates protesting against their exclusion from the Conference. They declare that they have come, mainly, to appeal to the Conference for protection from Japan who had broken her pledge to preserve the independence of Korea and was committing manifold barbarities. {Reuter)

The French proposal regarding a declaration of war was almost entirely unsupported! It is recognized to be impracticable. It is believed that France merely made the proposal on behalf of Russia. {Reuter)
Queen Wilhelmina received the delegates of the Peace Conference. (Havas)

div.head:
KHEDIVE IN CONSTANTINOPLE.
DINNER AT YILDIZ.

div.p: The Khedive dined at Yildiz Kiosk and was afterwards received in audience by the Sultan. He received several imperial favours. {Reuter)
A revenue cutter has captured 29 Japanese seal-poachers off St. Paul island. {Renter)
It is officially stated that 150 Greeks crossed the Thessalian frontier and penetrated to Monastir where they encountered the Imperial troops. The Greeks had 20 killed. {Reuter)

M. Etienne, on his return from Berlin, had a long interview with M. Pichon. It is asserted that in an interview with M. Etienne, Prince von Buelow confirmed the idea that German opinion was favourable to an understanding with France. (Havas)
The Crown Prince has started on a tour of the African colonies. (Renter)
The Tribunal has pronounced the divorce of Mr. Vodfin (Archduke Leopold). (Havas)
The municipal and provincial council elections have resulted in a victory for the people's party. (Havas)
The Chamber has opened the discussion on the income tax proposal. (Havas)
Count Nigra is dead. {Reuter)
Count Nigra, ex-Ambassador, is dead. (U.)

div.head: A PEEP AT CYPRUS.
A GARDEN ISLAND.
div.p: There has been much talk at home of garden cities. In Nicosia there is one ready-made. Within the circle of its Venetian ramparts there are groves of stately palms, feathery mimosas, sweet-scented Persian lilacs, and the bright glossy green of oranges and lemons starred with odorous blossoms. Houses occur as accidents in the mass of foliage. Walking in the narrow, winding streets, you wonder what has become of the trees until an open doorway reveals the spacious garden court overflowing with foliage, the tender hue of the vine mingling with the darker tints of the fig and relieved by the vivid scarlet of the pomegranate blooms. This is all within the walls. Outside there is the moat planted with eucalyptus which have attained the dimensions of forest trees, and, beyond, the roads lined with pines and the English bungalows smothered with roses and passion flowers. One may see the same thing elsewhere, but the gardens inside the city are unique. It would be safe to say that there are more flowers to the square mile than in any other city in the world. There is a street of cobblers, and every stall has its roof of vine. There is a street of blacksmiths, but even there the intruding green softens the sward hue of the forges.

The road from Larnaca is dull. Why Lamaca should be the chief port is not apparent. It is an open roadstead, and the town is in the midst of the least fertile portion of the island. On the other hand, Famagusta has a harbour with a quay 800 feet long and a depth of 24 feet of water alongside. It is connected with Nicosia by an excellent light railway traversing the richest grain district in Cyprus. They are getting in their harvest now, and the journey of 37 miles presents a succession of delightfal rural pictures. There is a gay note of colour in the Cypriote dress, both of men and women and the Messaoria plain is a sheet of gold diapered with patches of a lighter tint where the wheat and barley have fallen beneath the sickle. Famagusta itself is inhabited exclusively by Turks. They seem to live mainly by frequenting one another's cafes, and fill up their time between dawn and dusk by smoking nargilehs Outside the walls is the Greek town of Varosia. Here people work. Shoemakers, tailors, bakers, and shopkeepers ply their trades briskly, and here are the women shaping the pottery that has a reputation in the island and is modelled on forms which have obtained since the days when the heap of stones called Salomis was a city. Varosia stands for the modern Famagusta. Near the station is the Savoy Hotel, between which and the club the half dozen Englishmen whose work lies here divide their hours of leisure ; all except one—the harbour-master. He is planted among the Turks in a part of the fortifications known as Othello's Tower. There was, it seems, a Pro- veditore of the Signory of Venice here named Cristoforo Moro, though whether it was the original of Othello is not clear. But Shakespeare, from act ii, to act v., laid his scene at. Famagusta, and the worthy skipper is proud of his residence. He has turned the grim Venetian stronghold into a comfortable English home.

The city has undergone the shrinkage which marks every seat of former civilisation into which the Ottoman has stepped. There are vast waste spaces and the remains of thirty churches and several jmlaces. The Royal residence is now a police barracks and a prison containing pyramids of old stone, round shot, and queer pieces of artillery of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. The chief glory of the place is the Cathedral, now a mosque, and the strangest mosque, surely, in which a Mussulman ever prayed. It is a noble work of the early fourteenth century—pure French Gothic, with two western towers and a glorious apse with flying buttresses reminding one of Notre Dame. It is only by looking at the palm trees that we realise that we are not in some old cathedral town of the West. Here in the days of Famagusta's splendour the kings of Cyprus were crowned kings of Jerusalem, and here opposite the west front, in the last dreadfifl days of 1571, the brave defender of the fortress, Bragadino, was flayed alive while the statues of the saints were being dragged from these now empty niches and the Christian fane was being turned into a mosque. He had been lured into surrender by the infamous Mustafa under the promise took place in 1821. There are about 51,000 Turks in the island now. They are a quiet, inoffensive section of the population, but the land is slowly passing out of their hands into those of the more industrious Christian cultivators. They prefer employment under the Cyprus Government I found one reading a sixpenny edition of an English classic the other day; to one who knows anything of the Turks the incident was amazing. Not less so is the fact that, in addition to a high school for boys, they have another for girls, built chiefly by subscriptions from Moslems in Nicosia as a memorial to Queen Victoria.

We were on our way to the ruins of an ancient castle near Kyrenia a magnificent eagle sailed close overhead. "Aetos I" exclaimed the Greek boy who was our guide. He spoke the tongue of Homer, of whom he had never heard. The word took us away from the vestiges of mediaeval Cyprus and set us thinking of the many masters whom the island has known in its chequered history. It is tranquil under the present one. It might be more prosperous, but in contrast with what we had seen of late it is an Eden, and to the traveller fresh from Ottoman territory a delightful resting-place. ("Manchester Guardian")

div.head: THE LAMBERT CASE.
div.p: The following is text of the letter addressed to the Minister of Public Instruction by the late Director of the Khedivial School of Law.

Vous m'avez fait parvenir une petition par laquelle un certain nombre de jeunes gens sor- tant de l'enseignement secondaire vous de- mandent de faire ritablir £ l'Ecole de Droit les cours du soir. J'estime qu'il y aurait grand inconvenient £ donner suite k cette petition. Mes predecesseurs ont poursnivi, pendant de longues annees, l'experience des cours du soir. Cette experience a ete desastreuse. Je conserve dans les archives de mon secretariat la oopie d'une serie de rapports des presidents de commissions d'examen de fin d'annee qui tous cons- tatent l'insuffisance de preparation des aspirants £ la licence ayant frequents exclusive- ment les cours du soir.
Deja en 1895, le Conseiller Judiciaire, Sir J. Scott, ecrivait, dans son rapport sur les exa- mens, ces lignes caracteristiques :•—

"J'ai pu constater que la valeur des etudiants frequentant les cours du soir, et specialement de ceux de premiere et de seconde annee, est de beaucoup inferieure k celle de leurs condisciples des cours du jour. C'est egalement l'impression de M. Kassem Amin Bey, Conseiller k la Cour d'Appel indigene, qui apris avoir faitTdloge des elfcves de 2me annee des cours du jdur ajoute: (Malheureusement, je ne puis en dire autant des dfevea de 2me amfee du soir; sur sept que j'ai examines, j'ai dfi eri refuser quatre, c'estA-dire plus de la moitfe ; et je dois ajouter que ces trois que j'ai cru pouvoir admettre etaient peu briilants)."

Sir Malcolm Mcllwraith enregistrait, £ son tour, au lendemain de sa premiere visite a l'Ecole, les monies risultats decourageants, et je detache de son rapport sur les examens de 1898 un fragment qui montre assez ce qu'ont ete dans le passe les cours du soir et ce qa'ils seraient destines £ redevenir en cas de rita- blissement:—

"J'ai constate £ tous les examens auxquels j'aiassiste, que les ei&ves qui etaientnotablement inferieurs £ la moyenne, etaient toujours des efeves des cours du soir qui, etant gendrale- ment occopes dans la journee, ne peuvent pro- bablement pas consacrer un temps suffisant £ la preparation de leurs examens. Certes, il est tris meritoire que des jeunes gens qui sont forces de gagner leur vie en travaillant dans les Minist£res et ailleure dans la journee, con- sacrent leurs loisirs du soir £ l'acquisition de connaissances juridiques. Mais d'un autre c6te, comme la plupart de ces etudiants insuffisam- ment prepares sont admis, en fait, k leurs examens,—sou vent par suite d'une trop grande indulgence de la part des examinateurs,—il se forme peu a peu dans le pays un contingent de mauvais licencfes en droit qui, malgri leur insuffisance, sont ostensiblement tout aussi qualifies que d'autres pour des emplois dans la magistrature et les Ministeres pour lesquels il n'y a dej£ que trop d'aspirants."

C'est £ la suite et sous la pression de ces ptaintes, riguli&rement renouvelees chaque annee par les jurys d'examens, que le Miniature de l'lnstruction Publique decida de supprimer la section des cours du soir k partir de la ren- tree de 1898-1899. La reforme s'imposait par des raisons si ddcisives que le savant jurisconsults, le regrette Charles Testoud, qui avait pris l'initiative et la responsabilite de la creation de la section du soir, s'empressa lui-m£me, avec sa loyaute cou turn fere, de reconnaltre que l'opportunite de cette suppression etait £ l'abri de la discussion. Dans le rapport qu'il adres- sait au Miniature, le 9 Juin 1899, il avouait, non sans tristesse, les desiilusions que lui avait causees cette partie de son oeuvre :

" Il n'a plus, ecrit-il, ete admis d'dfeves pour la section du soir. Conformement aux suggestions de M. le Conseiller Judiciaire, cette section a ete abolie £ la rentree d'Octobre 1899, mais elle a ete abolie sans effets ritros- pectifs. Cette suppression doit Itre consideree comme avantagense au bien des etudes. Les efeves du soir etaient en effet d'une valeur inferieure, pour diverses causes que je n'ai pas £ appricier ioi. "

Si les cours du soir avaient subsiste jusqu'£ l'heure actuelle, l'ecart entre le niveau de culture de leur clientele et celui de la population scolaire riguli&re serait aujourd'hui beaucoup plus acouse encore, qu'en 1898 ; car, depuis. Le moment serait bien mal choisi de recom- mencer £ fabriquer, comme dan« la pdriode d'enfance de mon <*cole, des licencfes en droit au rabais et de qualitfe inferieure, quaniF l'affluence de la clientele scolaire aux cours actuels est ddj£ excessive ; quand nous nous demandons avec inquietude si le barreau et la et 1a magistrature pourront longtemps absorber des contingents de juristea aussi importants que ceux que nous fbrmons actuellement chaque annee. 150 etudiants se sont assis en 1906-1907 sur les bancs de ma premiere annee, et si mes renseignements sont exacts, l'Eoole fran9aise de Droit en a vu pris d'une centaine venir s'inscrire sur ses registres. Une production annuelle de pris de 250 licencfes est dejk >en flagrante disproportion avec les besoms riels du pays, et il semble difficile de meconnattre que, comme lfecrivait M. le Conseiller Khedivial Bem&rdi dans son rapport sur les examens de l'annee dernfere, l'offre des juristes ne va pas tarder £ depasser la demande. Est-ce k Thenre oh le marche egyptien des professions liberates va regorger de juristes jusqu'B satiete, et oh la lutte pour la vie va devenir trop dure pour que tous ceux des nouveaux venus qui ont fait des etudes suivies et rigalicres puissent se tailler une place au barreau, qu'il convient d'inviter k entrer en lice des concurrents qui, prepares k la hate et, par consequent, moins bien arafes, sont presque tous condamnes (Favance £ l'insucris ?

Pour qu'une section du soir ne fht pas une trop grossfere contrefa^on de l'ecole actuelle, il faudrait que ses etudiants s'astreignissent k suivre one moyenne de quatre heures de cours par soirie, avec une assiduite que l'ex- perience 3u pass$ a demoiitri 6tre incompatible avec les exigences de leurs professions. Pour la doter d'un personnel aussi nombreux et aussi competent que celui qui enseigne dans mes cours du jour, le Minisfere de l'lnstruction Publique devrait se resigner A d'importants sacrifices bndgetaires qui ne trouveraient ni leur justification ni leur recompense dans les resultats obtenus. Car le seul effet certain que nous puissions attendre d'un etablissement des cours du soir, c'est de pouaser un grand nombre de fonctionnaires £ quitter l'asile assure que leur offrent les carrferes administratives pour se lancer, sans preparation sdrieuse, dans la lutte pour la conquete de la clientele juridique, et de former ainsi une classe d'intellectuels desoeuvris et besogneux qui, ne trouvant, ni au barreau, ni dans la magistrature, I'emploi de son activite, risque de coastituer un element de trouble pour la societe.
J'ai confere, £ ce sujet, avec le Conseiller Judiciaire qui m'a dit qu'il partageait pleine- ment cette manfere de voir et maintenait l'opinion qu'il avait exprimee en 1898.
Veuillez agreer, je vous prie, Monsieur le Ministre, 1'assurance de mes sentiments dd- voues.
Le Directeur de FEcole de Droit Signe : En. Lambert.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: CRICKET.
ROYAL GARRISON ARTILLERY
versus
KS.R. INSTITUTE.

The second meeting of these clubs took place at Guezireh Badrane on Friday 28th. The Institute were unable to put a full team into the field, the absentees including W.B. Davies; the captain, P.G. Windsor, who officiated in his absence, won the toss and took out Eevd. J.T. Bums with him to bat. Just after doubles figures had been passed Revd. Bums got his foot in front of a straight one from Barnes. With the exception of Windsor the Institute batsmen failed to make any resistance against Barnes and Girton both of whom bowled exceptionally well. The total amounted to 61. The Gunners made anything but a promising start, Bradley being smartly taken behind the wicket when 2. On Sullivan and Burgess being partnered runs came quickly. Both men gave easy chances at the commencement of their innings but both were fortunate to be let off, and these mistakes cost the Institute the game. The home team's total was passed with five wickets down but the later men added only 16. The Gunners who reached 80 thus won by 19 runs and avenged their defeat by 158 earlier in the season. Appended are the scores
